repnme.cdata!:
Djibouti - International Road Corridor
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project development objective, as
            stated in the Development Credit Agreement, was to improve
            road access to the Port of Djibouti by rehabilitating the
            road and associated service infrastructure from the port to
            the Djibouti-Ethiopian border. The project objective
            remained unchanged during implementation. However, following
            the decision of the European Union to finance the long-term
            rehabilitation of the South Corridor (rather than the
            initially planned North Corridor), a supplemental credit was
            approved by IDA in May 2003 to enable more extensive and
            sustainable rehabilitation and maintenance works on the road
            between Djibouti and Galafi. Principal performance rating
            are as follows ; outcome was satisfactory; sustainability
            was likely; institutional development impact was modest;
            Bank and borrower performance was satisfactory. The report
            cites the following as lessons learned: 1) need of simple
            design in emergency operation. 2) In emergency operations,
            substantial training activities and intensive supervision
            efforts are required to build capacity and support for PIUs
            during initial stages of the project. 3) Difficulty in
            achieving institutional reforms in emergency operations. 4)
            The experience of this project confirms that in addition to
            general delays in project execution, the construction and
            supervision cost of force accounts are likely to be much
            higher that those of the private contractors. Finally, the
            project shows the importance of flexibility and timely
            responsiveness to changes in circumstances and client's
            needs. During implementation the Bank reacted well and took
            all actions necessary to secure achievement of the project
            objective despite the changed situation.

repnme.cdata!:
Djibouti - Supplemental Credit to the
            International Road Corridor Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This Supplemental Credit to the Djibouti
            International Road Corridor Rehabilitation Project Is needed
            to provide supplementary financing for the ongoing
            International Road Corridor Rehabilitation Project. It is
            crucial to complete the rehabilitation of the road which
            connects the Port of Djibouti with neighboring Ethiopia,
            which fully depends on the Djibouti port for all foreign
            maritime trade, and for the massive and recurrent shipments
            of food aid to millions of Ethiopians. The supplementary
            financing is needed to cover higher than expected costs for
            physical road rehabilitation works, and ultimately to allow
            the existing International Road Corridor Rehabilitation
            Project to reach its original development objectives. The
            proposed credit would be on standard IDA terms, with a
            maturity of 40 years.

repnme.cdata!:
Djibouti - International Road Corridor
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The International Road Corridor
            Rehabilitation Project aims to secure, over the medium-term,
            an acceptable level of service on the Djibouti-Galafi Road
            which constitutes Djibouti Port's transit corridor to
            Ethiopia, during the period when a long-term corridor
            improvement scheme is being developed and implemented by the
            Ethiopian and Djibouti governments with assistance from the
            European Union. The project consists of eleven components.
            They can be separated into two implementation phases: in the
            initial phase, quick rehabilitation and repairs of road
            between the Arta turnoff and Galaif, on the Ethiopia border
            over a period of about one year; and a second three-year
            phase covering road maintenance, construction of axle load
            control stations, and technical assistance to support
            institutional development. Phase I would have the following
            components: 1) civil works between Dikhil and Galafi, 2)
            civil works between Arta and Dikhil, and 3) rehabilitation
            of Roads Department's equipment pool. Phase II will
            have the following components: 4) routine maintenance of the
            entire Arta-spur to Galafi; 5) axle load control station; 6)
            project implementation unit; 7) construction management
            consultant and supervision of the works; 8) offices,
            vehicles and laboratory equipment for supervising engineer,
            construction manager, and Project Implementation Unit; 9)
            institutional development support,10) studies on HIV/AIDS
            and road safety, and 11) study on development of
            trade-related services.

repnme.cdata!:
Djibouti - Rehabilitation of International
            Road Corridor Project : environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rehabilitation of International Road
            Corridor Project will result in significant environmental,
            health, and safety improvements, although potential adverse
            environmental impacts during construction, will occur. These
            will be effectively addressed through engineering design,
            low cost mitigation measures, and construction monitoring,
            which will include specific environmental provisions for
            contractors. This Environmental Management Plan supports
            specific measures to mitigate construction, and operational
            impacts, as follows: 1) construction impacts will be reduced
            through detailed engineering design, and specific
            procurement requirements for handling management waste,
            including oil spills, and fuel, and lubricant leakage,
            mainly in the Port of Djibouti; 2) operational management
            will support road maintenance programs, during a three year
            period, to avoid deterioration, and ensure safety
            regulations. Further measures include adequate waste
            disposal, and adoption of health, and safety controls; 3)
            final designs for the road rehabilitation program will take
            into account storm water, and sediment management
            requirements for crossings, and culverts; 4) field
            investigations on archaeological sites will be conducted, to
            protect these, and burial sites from earth works; and, 5)
            support for HIV/AIDS education, and outreach programs is
            included in the plan.

Djibouti - Rehabilitation of International
